TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Euic, isohyperthermic Typic Haplosaprists

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON: Loxahatche muck on a concave dip in fresh water marsh. (Colors are for moist soil unless otherwise stated)
Oa1--0 to 69 centimeters (0 to 28 inches); dark brown (7.5YR 3/2) muck; about 30 percent fiber unrubbed and about 5 percent fiber rubbed; weak medium subangular blocky structure; very friable, soft; nonsticky, nonplastic; neutral; gradual wavy boundary.
Oa2--69 to 203 centimeters (28 to 80 inches); black (10YR 2/1) muck; about 35 percent fiber unrubbed and about 5 percent fiber rubbed; massive; very friable, soft, nonsticky, nonplastic; neutral.  Combined thickness of the Oa horizon is 69 to 203 centimeters (28 to 80 inches)

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION: Broward County, Florida; about 6 miles north of the intersection of I-75 and US 27; about 6 miles east of the boat launch; in the un-sectionized southern part of the Water Conservation Area 2A; latitude 26 degrees, 14 minutes, 21.05 seconds N and longitude 80 degrees, 22 minutes, 2.53 W; WGS84; USGS Cooper City, FL quadrangle.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:
Solum thickness: 203 centimeters or more
Depth to seasonally high water: 0 to 15 centimeters (0 to 6 inches)
Soil Reaction: Moderately acid to moderately alkaline
Depth of the organic material:  203 centimeters (80 inches)
Depth to bedrock:  greater than 203 centimeters (80 inches)
Fiber content: Un-Rubbed 10 to 70 percent and rubbed less than 17 percent

COMPETING SERIES.content:
COMPETING SERIES: These are the Buffalo Tiger and Keylargo series.
Buffalo Tiger soils--have bedrock at depths less than 203 centimeters (80 inches) and occur in similar landform positions.
Keylargo soils--have bedrock at depths less than 203 centimeters (80 inches), are subject to daily flooding by marine water, are dominated by mangroves, and occur in the tidal zone.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content:
GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:
Landscape: Florida Everglades
Landform(s): Talfs, rises, and/or dips in fresh water marshes and swamps
Parent material: organic materials formed from remains of hydrophytic herbaceous plant overlying limestone bedrock.
Mean annual air temperature: 24 to 26 degrees C (75 to 79 degrees F)
Mean annual precipitation: 112 to 160 centimeters (44 to 63 inches)

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content:
GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS: In addition to the competing Buffalo Tiger soils, these are:
Coopertown soils--have limestone bedrock within 20 to 51 centimeters (8 to 20 inches) of the surface and occur in similar landform positions.
Gator Lake soils--have limestone bedrock within 5 to 18 centimeters (2 to 7 inches) of the surface and occur in similar landform positions.
Macks Camp soils--have bedrock at depths of 102 to 130 centimeters (40 to 51 inches) and occur on similar landform positions.
Plantation soils--have sandy layers below the organic layer and above the limestone bedrock.Shark Valley soils--have bedrock at depths of 51 to 102 centimeters (20 to 40 inches) and are in similar landform positions.
Tamiami soils--have subsurface horizons of freshwater marl that compose less than 1/2 the thickness of the control section and occur in similar landform positions.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content:
DRAINAGE AND SATURATED HYDRAULIC CONDUCTIVITY:
Drainage class: Very poorly drained
Saturated hydraulic conductivity (Ksat): Very high to high
Permeability: Rapid
Surface runoff: Negligible
Flooding frequency and duration: None
Ponding frequency and duration: Under natural conditions the soil is covered by water (ponded) - very frequently for very long duration for 9 to 11 months, currently ponding is controlled by anthropogenic activities.
Hydric Indicators: A1 Histosol, A3 Black Histic, and A8 Muck Presence

USE AND VEGETATION.content:
USE AND VEGETATION:
Major Uses: Water quality, water storage, and wildlife habitat.
Dominant vegetation: sawgrass, sedges, lilies, spikerush, willow, elderberry, pond apple, and cypress.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Florida Everglades and associated areas.  This soil is of moderate extent

REGIONAL OFFICE.content: SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (SSRO) RESPONSIBLE:  Raleigh, North Carolina.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS: Diagnostic horizons and features in this pedon include:
1.	Particle-size control section: ranges from 0 to 203 centimeters (0 to 80 inches)
2.	Histic epipedon: 0 to 69 centimeters (0 to 28 inches) (Oa1 horizon)
3.	Aquic conditions: Endosaturation ranges from 0 to 203 centimeters (0 to 80 inches)
This soil was previous mapped as Terra Ceia, which is in the hyperthermic temperature regime.
Soil Series was classified according to the 12th Edition of the Keys to Soil Taxonomy.
ADDITIONAL DATA:
Laboratory data is available on the National Soil Survey website at: http://ncsslabdatamart.sc.egov.usda.gov/querypage.aspx
